div.p: WIVES AS THEY WERE, AND MAIDS AS THEY ARE, A COMEDY, IN FIVE ACTS. PERFORMED AT THE THEATRE ROYAL, COVENT-GARDEN.
DUBLIN: PRINTED FOR P. WOGAN, OLD-BRIDGE. 1797.

sp.l: I COME not to announce a baſhful maid
Who ne'er has try'd the drama's doubtful trade,
Who ſees with flutt'ring hope the curtain riſe,
And ſcans with timid glance your critic eyes;
My client is a more experienc'd dame,
Tho' not a Veteran, not unknown to Fame,
Who think your favours are an honeſt boaſt,
Yet fears to forfeit what ſhe values moſt;
Who has, ſhe truſts, ſome character to loſe,
E'en tho' the woman did not aid the Muſe;
Who courts with modeſt aim the public ſmile,
That ſtamp of merit, and that meed of toil.
At Athens once (our author has been told)
The Comic Muſe, irregularly bold,
With living calumny profan'd her ſtage,
And forg'd the frailties of the faultleſs ſage.
Such daring ribaldry you need not fear,
We have no Socrates to libel here.
Ours are the follies of an humbler flight,
Offspring of manners volatile and light;
Our gen'ral ſatire keeps more knaves in awe,
Our court of conſcience comes in aid of law.
Here ſcourg'd by wit, and pilloried by fun,
Ten thouſand coxcombs bluſh inſtead of one.
If ſcenes like theſe could make the guilty ſhrink,
Could teach unfeeling Folly how to think,
Check Affectation's voluble career,
And from cold Faſhion force the ſtruggling tear,
Our author would our loudeſt praiſe forego,
Content to feel within "what paſſes ſhow,"
"But ſince" (ſhe ſays) "ſuch hopes cannot be mine,
"Such bold pretenſions I muſt needs reſign,
"Tell theſe great judges, of dramatic laws,
"Their reformation were my beſt applauſe;
"Yet if the heart my proud appeal withſtands,
"I aſk the humbler ſuffrage of their hands."

div.head: WIVES AS THEY WERE. AND MAIDS AS THEY ARE.
SCENE I. An Apartment at Mr. NORBERRY's
div.stage: Enter Sir WILLIAM DORRILLON, and Mr. NORBERRY.

sp.speaker: Mr. NORBERRY.
sp.p: WHY blame me?—Why blame me?—My ſiſter had the ſole management of your daughter by your own authority; from the age of ſix years, till within eight months of the preſent time, when, in conſequence of my ſiſter's death, ſhe was transferred to my protection.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: Your ſiſter, Mr. Norberry, was a prudent, good woman—ſhe never could inſtruct her in all this vice.

sp.speaker: Mr. Nor.
sp.p: Depend upon it, my dear friend, that Miſs Dorrillon, your daughter, came to my houſe juſt the ſame heedleſs woman of faſhion you now ſee her.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: impatiently. Very well—'Tis very well.—But, when I think on my diſappointment—

sp.speaker: Mr. Nor.
sp.p: There is nothing which may not be repaired. Maria, with you for a guide—

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: Me! She turns me into ridicule—laughs at me! This morning, as ſhe was enumerating ſome of her frivolous expences, ſhe obſerved me lift up my hands and ſigh; on which ſhe named fifty other extravagances ſhe had no occaſion to mention, merely to enjoy the pang which every ſolly of her ſends to my heart.

sp.speaker: Mr. Nor.
sp.p: But do not charge this conduct of your daughter to the want of filial love:—did ſhe know you were ſir William Dorrillon, did ſhe know you were her father, every word you uttered, every look you glanced, would be received with gentleneſs and ſubmiſſion:—but your preſent rebukes from Mr. Mandred (as you are called), from a perfect ſtranger, as ſhe ſuppoſes, ſhe conſiders as an impertinence which ſhe has a right to reſent.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: I wiſh I had continued abroad. And yet, the hope of beholding her, and of beſtowing upon her the riches I acquired, was my ſole ſupport through all the toils by which I gained them.

sp.speaker: Mr. Nor.
sp.p: And, conſidering her preſent courſe of life, your riches could not come more opportunely.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: She ſhall never have a farthing of them. Do you think I have encountered the perils of almoſt every climate, to ſquander my hard-earned fortune upon the paltry vicious pleaſures in which ſhe delights? No.—I have been now in your houſe exactly a month—I will ſtay but one day longer—and then, without telling her who I am, I will leave the kingdom and her for ever—Nor ſhall ſhe know that this inſignificant merchant whom ſhe deſpiſes, was her father, till he is gone, never to be recalled.

sp.speaker: Mr. Nor.
sp.p: You are offended with ſome juſtice, but, as I have often told you, your exceſſive delicacy and reſpect for the conduct of the other ſex, degenerate into rigour.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: True—for what I ſee ſo near perfection as woman, I want to ſee perfect. We, Mr. Norberry, can never be perfect; but ſurely women, women, might eaſily be made angels!

sp.speaker: Mr. Nor.
sp.p: And if they were, we ſhould ſoon be glad to make them into women again.

sp.speaker: Sir William
sp.p: —She ſets the example. She gives the faſhion!—and now your Whole houſe, and all your viſitors, in imitation of her, treat me with levity, or with contempt.—But I'll go away to-morrow.

sp.speaker: Mr. Nor.
sp.p: Can you deſert your child in the moment ſhe wants your protection? That exquiſite beauty juſt now become mature—

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: There's my difficulty!—There's my ſtruggle!—If ſhe were not ſo like her mother, I could leave her without a pang—caſt hey off, and think no more of her.—But that ſhape! that face! thoſe ſpeaking looks! Yet, how reverſed!—Where is the diffidence, the humility—where is the ſimplicity of my beloved wife? Buried in her grave.

sp.speaker: Mr. Nor.
sp.p: And, in all this great town, you may never ſee even its apparition.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: I rejoice, however, at the ſtratagem by which I have gained a knowledge of her heart: deprived by the means of ſearching it in her early years, had I at preſent come as her father, ſhe might have deceived me with counterfeit manners, till time diſcloſed the impoſition.—Now at leaſt, I am not impoſed upon.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Lord Priory. Exit.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: Lord Priory!

sp.speaker: Mr. Nor.
sp.p: An old acquaintance of mine, though we ſeldom meet. He has ſome ſingularities; and yet, perhaps—

sp.speaker: Mr. Nor.
sp.p: My dear Lord, I am glad to ſee you. Mr. Mandred introducing Sir Willian. My Lord, I hope I ſee you in perfect health.

sp.speaker: Lord Pri.
sp.p: Yes: but in very ill humour. I came to London early this morning with my family for the winter, and found my houſe, after going through only a ſlight repair, ſo damp, that I dare not ſleep in it: and ſo I am now ſending and going all over the town to ſeek for lodgings.

sp.speaker: Mr. Nor.
sp.p: Then ſeek no farther, but take up your lodgings here.

sp.speaker: Lord Pri.
sp.p: To be plain with you, I called in hopes you would aſk me; for I am ſo delicately ſcrupulous in reſpect to lady Priory, that I could not bear the thought of taking her to an hotel.

sp.speaker: Mr. Nor.
sp.p: Then pray return home, and bring her hither immediately, with all your luggage.

sp.speaker: Lord Pri.
sp.p: I am moſt extremely obliged to you very fervently; for into no one houſe belonging to any of my acquaintance would I take my wife, ſo ſoon as into yours. I have now been married eleven years, and during all that time I have made it a rule never to go on a viſit, ſo as to domeſticate, in the houſe of a married man.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: May I enquire the reaſon of that?

sp.speaker: Lord Pri.
sp.p: It is becauſe I am married myſelf; and having always treated my wife according to the ancient mode of treating wives, I would rather ſhe ſhould never be an eye-witneſs to the modern houſehold management.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: The ancients, I believe, were very affectionate to their wives.

sp.speaker: Lord Pri.
sp.p: And they had reaſon to be ſo; for their wives obeyed them. The ancients ſeldom gave them the liberty to do wrong: but modern wives do as they like.

sp.speaker: Mr. Nor.
sp.p: And don't you ſuffer Lady Priory to do as ſhe likes?

sp.speaker: Lord Pri.
sp.p: Yes, when it is what I like too. But never, never elſe.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: Does not this draw upon you the character of an unkind huſband?

sp.speaker: Lord Pri.
sp.p: That I am proud of. Did you never obſerve, that ſeldom a breach of fidelity in a wiſe is expoſed where the unfortunate huſband is not ſaid to be "the beſt creature in the world! Poor man, ſo good-natured!—Doatingly fond of his wife!—Indulged her in every thing!—How cruel in her to ſerve him ſo!" Now, if I am ſerved ſo, it ſhall not be for my good-nature.

sp.speaker: Mr. Nor.
sp.p: But I hope you equally diſapprove of every ſeverity.

sp.speaker: Lord Pri.
sp.p: rapidly. What do you mean by ſeverity?

sp.speaker: Mr. Nor.
sp.p: You know you uſed to be rather violent in your temper.

sp.speaker: Lord Pri.
sp.p:
So I am ſtill—apt to be haſty and paſſionate
—but that is rather of advantage to me as a huſband—it cauſes me to be obeyed without heſitation—no liberty for contention, tears, or repining. I inſure conjugal ſunſhine, by now and then introducing a ſtorm; while ſome huſbands never ſee any thing but a cloudy ſky, and all for the want of a little domeſtic thunder to clear away the vapours.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: I have long conceived indulgenee to be the bane of female happineſs.

sp.speaker: Lord Pri.
sp.p: And ſo it is.—I know ſeveral women of faſhion who will viſit ſix place of different amuſement on the ſame night, have company at home beſides, and yet, for want of ſomething more, they'll be out of ſpirits: my wife never goes to a public place, has ſcarce ever company at home, and yet is always in ſpirits.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: Never viſits operas, or balls, or routs?

sp.speaker: Lord Pri.
sp.p: How ſhould ſhe? She goes to bed every night exactly at ten.

sp.speaker: Mr. Nor.
sp.p: In the name of wonder, how have you been able to bring her to that?

sp.speaker: Lord Pri.
sp.p: By making her riſe every morning at five.

sp.speaker: Mr. Nor.
sp.p: And ſo ſhe becomes tired before night.

sp.speaker: Lord Pri.
sp.p: Tired to death. Or, if I ſee her eyes completely open at bed-time, and ſhe aſks me to play one game more at piquet, the next morning I jog her elbow at half after four.

sp.speaker: Mr. Nor.
sp.p: But ſuppoſe ſhe does not reply to the ſignal?

sp.speaker: Lord Pri.
sp.p: Then I turn the key of the door when I leave the chamber; and there I find her when I come home in the evening.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: And without her having ſeen a creature all day?

sp.speaker: Lord Pri.
sp.p: This is in my favour; for not having ſeen a ſingle ſoul, ſhe is rejoiced even to ſee me.

sp.speaker: Mr. Nor.
sp.p: And will ſhe ſpeak to you after ſuch uſage?

sp.speaker: Lord Pri.
sp.p: If you only conſidered how much a woman longs to ſpeak after being kept a whole day ſilent, you would not aſk that queſtion.

sp.speaker: Mr. Nor.
sp.p: Well! this is the moſt ſurpriſing method!

sp.speaker: Lord Pri.
sp.p: Not at all. In ancient days, when manners were ſimple and pure, did not wives wait at the table of their huſbands? and did not angels witneſs the ſubordination? I have taught Lady Priory to practiſe the ſame humble docile obedience—to pay reſpect to her huſband in every ſhape and every form, no careleſs inattention to me—no ſmiling politeneſs to others in preference to me——no putting me up in a corner—in all aſſemblies, ſhe conſiders her huſband as the firſt perſon.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: I am impatient to ſee her.

sp.speaker: Lord Pri.
sp.p: But don't expect a fine lady with high feathers; and the et caetera of an Eaſtern concubine; you will ſee a modeſt plain English woman, with a cap on her head, a handkerchief on her neck, and a gown of our own manufacture.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: My friend Norberry, what a contraſt muſt there be between Lady Priory and the ladies in this houſe!

sp.speaker: Lord Pri.
sp.p: ſtarting. Have you ladies in this houſe?

sp.speaker: Mr. Nor.
sp.p: Don't be alarmed; they are both ſingle, and can give Lady Priory no ideas concerning the marriage ſtate.

sp.speaker: Lord Pri.
sp.p: Are you ſure of that? Some ſingle women are more informed than their friends believe.

sp.speaker: Mr. Nor.
sp.p: For theſe ladies, notwithſtanding a few (what you would call) exceſſes, I will anſwer.

sp.speaker: Lord Pri.
sp.p: Well, then, I and my wife will be with you about nine in the evening; you know we go to-bed at ten.

sp.speaker: Mr. Nor.
sp.p: But remember you bring your own ſervants to wait on you at five in the morning.

sp.speaker: Lord Pri.
sp.p: I ſhall bring but one—my old ſervant Oliver, who knows all my cuſtoms ſo well, that I never go any where without him.

sp.speaker: Mr. Nor.
sp.p: And is that old ſervant your valet ſtill?

sp.speaker: Lord Pri.
sp.p:
No, he is now a kind of gentleman in waiting. I have had no employment for a valet
ſince I married:—my wife, for want of diſſipation, has not only time to attend upon herſelf, but upon me. Do you think I could ſuffer a clumſy man to tie on my neckcloth, or comb out my hair, when the ſoft, delicate, and tender hands of my wife are at my command?Exit.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: After this amiable deſcription of a woman, how can I endure to ſee her, whom reaſons bids me deteſt; but whom nature ſtill—

sp.speaker: Mr. Nor.
sp.p: Here ſhe comes; and her companion in folly along with her.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: There's another woman! that Lady Mary Raffle? How can you ſuffer ſuch people in your houſe?

sp.speaker: Mr. Nor.
sp.p: She is only on a viſit for a few months—ſhe comes every winter, as her family and mine have long been intimately connected.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: Let us go. Let us go. I can't bear the ſight of them. Going.

sp.speaker: Mr. Nor.
sp.p: Stay, and for once behave with politeneſs and good humour to your daughter—do—and I dare venture my life, ſhe will neither inſult nor treat you with diſreſpect. You know you always begin firſt.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: Have not I a right to begin firſt?

sp.speaker: Mr. Nor.
sp.p: But that is a right of which ſhe is ignorant.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: And deſerves to be ſo, and ever ſhall be ſo. I ſtay and treat her with politeneſs and good humour? No—rather let her kneel and implore my pardon.

sp.speaker: Mr. Nor.
sp.p: Suffer me to reveal who you are, and ſo ſhe will.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: If you expoſe me only by the inſinuation to her knowledge, our friendſhip is that moment at an end.

sp.speaker: Mr. Nor.
sp.p: Firmly. I have already given you my promiſe on that ſubject; and you may rely upon it.

sp.speaker: Sir. Wil.
sp.p: I thank you—I believe you—and I thank you.

div.stage: Exeunt Sir William and Mr. Norberry.
Enter Lady Mary Raffle and Miſs Dorrillon.

sp.speaker: Miſs Dor.
sp.p: Stealing on as Mr. Norberry and Sir William leave the ſtage. They are gone. Thank heaven they are gone out of this room, for I expect a dozen viſiters; and Mr. Norberry looks ſo gloomy upon me, he puts me out of ſpirits: while that Mandred's peeviſhneſs is not to be borne.

sp.speaker: Lady M.
sp.p: Be ſatisfied; for you were tolerably ſevere upon him this morning in your turn.

sp.speaker: Miſs Dor.
sp.p: Why, I am vext—and I, don't like to be found fault with in my beſt humour, much leſs when I have ſo many things to teaſe me.

sp.speaker: Lady M.
sp.p: What are they?

sp.speaker: Miſs Dor.
sp.p: I have now loſt all my money, and all my jewels, at play; it is almoſt two years ſince I have received a ſingle remittance from my father; and Mr. Norberry refuſes to advance me a ſhilling more.—What I ſhall do to diſcharge a debt which muſt be paid either to-day or to-morrow, heaven knows!—Dear Lady Mary, you could lend me a ſmall ſum, could you?

sp.speaker: Lady M.
sp.p: Who? I! with ſurpriſe—My dear creature, it was the very thing I was going to aſk of you: for when you have money, I know no one ſo willing to diſperſe it among her friends.

sp.speaker: Miſs Dor.
sp.p: Am not I?—I proteſt I love to part with my money; for I know with what pleaſure I receive it myſelf, and I like to ſee that joy ſparkle in another's eye, which has ſo often brightened my own. But laſt night ruined me—I muſt have money ſomewhere—As you can't aſſiſt me, I muſt aſk Mr. Norberry for his carriage, and immediately go in ſearch of ſome friend that can lend me four, or five, or ſix, or ſeven hundred pounds. But the worſt is, I have loſt my credit—Is not that dreadful?

sp.speaker: Lady M.
sp.p: Yes, yes, I know what it is. Shaking her head.

sp.speaker: Miſs Dor.
sp.p: What will become of me?

sp.speaker: Lady M.
sp.p: Why don't you marry, and throw all misfortunes upon your huſband?

sp.speaker: Miſs Dor.
sp.p: Why don't you marry? For you have as many to throw.

sp.speaker: Lady M.
sp.p: But not ſo many lovers who would be willing to receive the load. I have no Sir George Evelyn with ten thouſand pounds a year—no Mr. Bronzely.

sp.speaker: Miſs Dor.
sp.p: If you have not now, you once had; for I am ſure Bronzely once paid his addreſſes to you.

sp.speaker: Lady M.
sp.p: And you have the vanity to ſuppoſe you took him from me?

sp.speaker: Miſs Dor.
sp.p: Silence.—Reſerve your anger to defend, and not to attack me. We ſhould be allies by the common ties of poverty: and 'tis time to arm; for here's the enemy.

div.stage: Enter Sir William with Mr. Norberry.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: They are here full. Aſide to Mr. Norberry, and offering to go back.

sp.speaker: Mr. Nor.
sp.p: Preventing him. No, no.

sp.speaker: Miſs Dor.
sp.p: I have been waiting here, Mr. Norberry, to aſk a favour of you. He and Sir William come forward. Will you be ſo kind as to lend me your carriage for a couple of hours?

sp.speaker: Mr. Nor.
sp.p: Mr. Mandred pointing to Sir William aſked me for it to take him into the city.

sp.speaker: Lady M.
sp.p: Oh, Mr. Mandred will give it up to Miſs Dorrillon, I am ſure: he can defer his buſineſs till to-morrow.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: No, Madam, ſhe may as well put off hers. I have money to receive, and I can't do it.

sp.speaker: Miſs Dor.
sp.p: I have money to pay, and I can't do it.

sp.speaker: Lady M.
sp.p: If one is going to receive, and the other to pay money, I think the beſt way is for you to go together; and then, what deficiency there is on one ſide, the other may ſupply.

sp.speaker: Miſs Dor.
sp.p: Will you conſent, Mr. Mandred?—Come, do; and I'll be friends with you.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: "She'll be friends with me!"

sp.speaker: Miſs Dor.
sp.p: Will you?

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Miſs Dor.
sp.p: Well, I certainly can aſk a favour of Mr. Mandred better than I can of any perſon in the world.

sp.speaker: Mr. Nor.
sp.p: Why ſo, Maria?

sp.speaker: Miſs Dor.
sp.p: Becauſe, inſtead of pain, I can ſee it gives him pleaſure to refuſe me.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: I never confer a favour, of the moſt trivial kind, where I have no eſteem.

sp.speaker: Miſs Dor.
sp.p: proudly. Nor would I receive a favour, of the moſt trivial kind, from one who has not liberality to eſteem me.

sp.speaker: Mr. Nor.
sp.p: Come, Miſs Dorrillon, do not grow ſerious; laugh as much as you pleaſe, but ſay nothing that—

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: To her impatiently. From whom then can you ever receive favours, except from the vain, the idle, and the depraved?—from thoſe whoſe lives are paſſed in begging them of others?

sp.speaker: Miſs Dor.
sp.p: They are the perſons who know beſt how to be on them: for my part, had I not ſometimes felt what it was to want a friend, I might never have had humanity to be the friend of another.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Sir George Evelyn.

sp.speaker: Mr. Nor.
sp.p: And pray, my dear, whoſe friend have you ever been?— Enter Sir George Evelyn.—Not Sir George Evelyn's, I am ſure; and yet he of all others deſerves your friendſhip moſt.

sp.speaker: Miſs Dor.
sp.p: But friendſhip will not content him: as ſoon as he thought he had gained that.—

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.p: He aſpired to the ſupreme happineſs of your love.

sp.speaker: Miſs Dor.
sp.p: Now you talk of "ſupreme happineſs," have you provided tickets for the fête on Thurſday?

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.p: I have: provided you have obtained Mr. Norberry's leave to go.

sp.speaker: Mr. Nor.
sp.p: That I cannot grant.

sp.speaker: Miſs Dor.
sp.p: Nay, my dear Sir, do not force me to go without it.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: with violence. Would you dare?

sp.speaker: Miſs Dor.
sp.p: looking with ſurpriſe."Would I dare," Mr. Mandred!—and what have you to ſay if I do?

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: Recollecting himſelf. I was only going to ſay, that if you did, and I were Mr. Norberry—

sp.speaker: Miſs Dor.
sp.p: And if you were Mr. Norberry, and treated me in the manner you now do, depend upon it I ſhould not think your approbation or diſapprobation, your pleaſure or diſpleaſure, of the ſlighteſt conſequence.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: greatly agitated. I dare ſay not—I dare ſay not. Good morning, Sir George—I dare ſay not.—Good morning, Mr. Norberry. Going.

sp.speaker: Mr. Nor.
sp.p: Stop a moment.—Maria, you have offended Mr. Mandred.

sp.speaker: Miſs Dor.
sp.p: He has offended me.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: at the door going off. I ſhan't offend you long.

sp.speaker: Mr. Norberry
sp.p: going to him and taking him by the arm. Stay, Mr. Mandred; Miſs Dorrillon, make an apology: Mr. Mandred is my friend, and you muſt not treat him with this levity.

sp.speaker: Lady M.
sp.p: No, no apology.

sp.speaker: Miſs Dor.
sp.p: No, no apology. But I'll tell you what I'll do. Goes up to Sir William——If Mr. Mandred likes, I'll ſhake hands with him—and we'll be good friends for the future. But then don't find fault with me—I can't bear it. You don't like to be found fault with yourſelf—You look as croſs as any thing every time I ſay the leaſt word againſt you. Come, ſhake hands; and don't let us ſee one another's failings for the future.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: There is no future for the trial.

sp.speaker: Miſs Dor.
sp.p: How do you mean?

sp.speaker: Mr. Nor.
sp.p: Mr. Mandred ſets off again for India to-morrow.

sp.speaker: Miſs Dor.
sp.p: Indeed! I thought he was come to live in England! I am ſorry you are going.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: with earneſtneſs. Why ſorry?

sp.speaker: Miſs Dor.
sp.p:
Becauſe we have ſo frequently quarrelled. I am always unhappy when I am going to be parted from a perſon with whom I have diſagreed;
I often think I could part with leſs regret from a friend.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: Not, I ſuppoſe, if the quarrel is forgiven?

sp.speaker: Miſs Dor.
sp.p: Ah! but Mr. Mandred does not forgive! no! in his looks I can always ſee reſentment.—Sometimes indeed I have traced a ſpark of kindneſs, and have gently tried to blow it to a little flame of friendſhip, when, with one haſty puff I have put it out.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: You are right. It is—I believe—extinguiſhed.

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.p: A very ſingular man.

sp.speaker: Lady M.
sp.p: Oh! If he was not rich, there would be no bearing him—Indeed he ſeems to have loſt all his friends; for during the month he has been here, I never found he had any one acquaintance out of this houſe.

sp.speaker: Miſs Dor.
sp.p: And what is very ſtrange, he has taken an averſion to me.—But it is ſtill more ſtrange, that although I know he has, yet in my heart I like him. He is moroſe to an inſufferable degree; but then, when by chance he ſpeaks kind, you cannot imagine how it ſoothes me.—He wants compaſſion and all the tender virtues; and yet, I frequently think, that if any ſerious misfortune were to befall me, he would be the firſt perſon to whom I ſhould fly to complain.

sp.speaker: Lady M.
sp.p: Then why don't you fly and tell him of your misfortune laſt night.

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.p: ſtarting. What misfortune?

sp.speaker: Miſs Dor.
sp.p: to lady Mary. Huſh!

sp.speaker: Lady M.
sp.p: A loſs at play— To Miſs Dor.—I beg your pardon, but it was out before you ſaid huſh.

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.p: Ah! Maria, will you ſtill riſk your own and my happineſs?

sp.speaker: Miſs Dor.
sp.p: Your happineſs and mine, Sir!—I beg you will not place them ſo near to each other.

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.p: Mine is ſo firmly fixed on you, it can only exiſt in yours.

sp.speaker: Lady M.
sp.p: Then, when ſhe is married to Mr. Bronzely, you will be happy becauſe ſhe will be ſo?

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.p: Bronzely! has he dared?

sp.speaker: Miſs Dor.
sp.p: Have not you dared, Sir?

sp.speaker: Lady M.
sp.p: But I believe Mr. Bronzely is the moſt daring of the two— aſide to Sir Geo—take care of him. Exit.

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.p: Miſs Dorrillon, I will not affront you by ſuppoſing that you mean ſeriouſly to receive the addreſſes of Mr. Bronzely; but I warn you againſt giving others, who know you leſs than I do, occaſion to think ſo.

sp.speaker: Miſs Dor.
sp.p: I never wiſh to deceive any one—I do admit of Mr. Bronzely's addreſſes.

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.p: Why, he is the profeſſed lover of your friend Lady Mary! or granting he denies it, and that I even paſs over the frivolity of the coxcomb, ſtill he is unworthy of you.

sp.speaker: Miſs Dor.
sp.p: He ſays the ſame of you; and half a dozen more ſay exactly the ſame of each other. If you like, I'll diſcard every one of you as unworthy; but if I retain you, I will retain the reſt. Which do you chooſe?

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.p: I ſubmit to any thing rather than the total loſs of you—But remember, that your felicity—

sp.speaker: Miſs Dor.
sp.p: "Felicity! felicity!"—ah! that is a word not to be found in the vocabulary of my ſenſations!— ſighing.

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.p: I believe you, and have always regarded you with a compaſſion that has augmented my love. In your infancy deprived of the watchful eye and anxious tenderneſs of a mother; the manly caution and authority of a father: miſled by the brilliant vapour of faſhion; ſurrounded by enemies in the garb of friends—Ah! do you weep? bleſſed, bleſſed be the ſign!—Suffer me to dry thoſe tears I have cauſed, and to give you a knowledge of true felicity.

sp.speaker: Miſs Dor.
sp.p:
recovering. I am very angry with myſelf.—Don't, I beg, tell Mr. Norberry or Mr. Mandred you ſaw me cry—they'll ſuppoſe I have
been move indiſcreet ſtifling her tears than I really have. For in reality I have nothing—

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.p: Do not endeavour to conceal from me, what my tender concern for you has given me the means to become acquainted with. I know you are plunged in difficulties by your father neither ſending nor coming, as you once expected: I know you are ſtill deeper plunged by your fondneſs for play.

sp.speaker: Miſs Dor.
sp.p: Very well, Sir! proceed.

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.p: Thus, then—Suffer me to ſend my ſteward to you this morning; he ſhall regulate your accounts, and place them in a ſtate that ſhall protect you from further embarraſſment till your father ſends to you; or protect you from his reproaches, ſhould he arrive.

sp.speaker: Miſs Dor.
sp.p: Sir George, I have liſtened to your detail of vices, which I acknowledge, with patience, with humility—but your ſuſpicion of thoſe which I have not, I treat with pride, with indignation.

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.p: How! ſuſpicion!

sp.speaker: Miſs Dor.
sp.p: What part of my conduct, Sir, has made you dare to ſuppoſe I would extricate myſelf from the difficulties that ſurround me, by the influence I hold over the weakneſs of a lover?

div.head: SCENE I. Another Apartment at Mr. Norberry's.
div.stage: Enter two Porters from an upper Entrance, bringing in Trunks; Lord Priory and Mr. Norberry following.

sp.speaker: Mr. NORBERRY.
sp.p: HERE, Stephens, why are you out of the way? Shew the men with theſe boxes into the dreſſing-room appointed for my Lord Priory.

div.stage: A Servant enters on the oppoſite ſide, and the Porters follow him off at the lower entrance on that ſide.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: My Lord, I hope I ſee you well this evening.

sp.speaker: Lord Pri.
sp.p: Yes Sir—and you find I have literally accepted Mr. Norberry's invitation, and am come to him with all my luggage.

div.stage: Enter Oliver with a ſmall box in each hand.

sp.speaker: Lord Pri.
sp.p: Follow thoſe men with the trunks, Oliver.

sp.speaker: Mr. Nor.
sp.p: Ah, Mr. Oliver, how do you do?

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.p: Pretty well—tolerably well, I thank you, Sir. Exit.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Lady Priory.
to her. Mr. Norberry, our worthy hoſt; and Mr. Mandred. She curtſies.

sp.speaker: Mr. Nor.
sp.p: I hope your ladyſhip will find my houſe ſo little inconvenient to you, as to induce you to make no very ſhort viſit.

sp.speaker: Lady Pri.
sp.p: I have no doubt, Sir, but I ſhall find, from your friendſhip, every comfort in this houſe which it is poſſible for me to enjoy out of my own.

div.stage: Enter Lady Mary Raffle and Miſs Dorrillon.

sp.speaker: Mr. Nor.
sp.p: introducing them Lady Priory—Lady Mary Raffle—Miſs Dorrillon—Lord Priory.

sp.speaker: Lady M.
sp.p: Permit me, Lady Priory, to take you to the next room: we are going to have tea immediately.

sp.speaker: Lady Pri.
sp.p: I have drank tea, Madam.

sp.speaker: Miſs Dor.
sp.p: Already! It is only nine o'clock.

sp.speaker: Lady Pri.
sp.p: Then it is near my hour of going to bed.

div.stage: Lord Priory, Sir William, and Mr. Norberry retire to the back of the ſtage, and talk apart.

sp.speaker: Lady M.
sp.p: Go to bed already! In the name of wonder, what time did you riſe this morning?

sp.speaker: Lady Pri.
sp.p: Why, I do think it was almoſt ſix o'clock.

sp.speaker: Lady M.
sp.p: in amaze And were you up at ſix this morning?

sp.speaker: Lady Pri.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Miſs Dor.
sp.p: At ſix in the month of January!

sp.speaker: Lady M.
sp.p: It is not light till eight; and what good, now, could you poſſibly be doing for two hours by candle-light?

sp.speaker: Lady Pri.
sp.p: Pray, Lady Mary, at what time did you go to bed?

sp.speaker: Lady M.
sp.p: About three this morning.

sp.speaker: Lady Pri.
sp.p: And what good could you poſſibly be doing for eleven hours by candle-light?

sp.speaker: Lady M.
sp.p: Good! It's as much as can be expected from a woman of faſhion, if ſhe does no 〈◊〉

sp.speaker: Lady Pri.
sp.p:
But I ſhould fear you woul •
〈…〉 deal of harm to your health, your ſpirits, and the tranquillity of your mind.

div.stage: Mr. Norberry goes off—Lord Priory and Sir William come forward.

sp.speaker: Lady M.
sp.p: Oh, my Lord Priory, I really find all the accounts I have heard of your education for a wife to be actually true!—and I can't help laughing to think, if you and I had chanced to have married together, what a different creature you moſt likely would have made of me, to what I am at preſent.

sp.speaker: Lord Pri.
sp.p: Yes! and what a different creature you moſt likely would have made of me, to what I am at preſent.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: Lady Priory, I am not accuſtomed to pay compliments or to ſpeak my approbation, even when praiſe is a juſt tribute; but your virtues compel me to an eulogium. That wiſe ſubmiſſion to a huſband who loves you, that chearful ſmile ſo expreſſive of content, and that plain dreſs which indicates the elegance as well as the ſimplicity, of your mind, are all ſymbols of a heart ſo unlike to thoſe which the preſent faſhion of the day has miſled———

sp.speaker: Miſs Dor.
sp.p: Why look ſo ſtedfaſtly on me, Mr. Mandred? Do you pretend to ſee my heart?

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: Have you any?

sp.speaker: Miſs Dor.
sp.p: Yes; one large enough to hold—even my enemy.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Mr. Bronzely.

sp.speaker: Miſs Dor.
sp.p: Shew him into the other room. Exit Servant. Come, Lady Priory, we muſt introduce you to Mr. Bronzely: he is one of the moſt faſhionable, agreeable, pleaſant, whimſical, unthinking, and ſpirited creatures in all the world: you'll be charmed—

sp.speaker: Lady Pri.
sp.p: I dare ſay it's near ten o'clock. I am afraid I ſhan't be able to keep awake.

sp.speaker: Miſs Dor.
sp.p: You muſt—We are going to have a little concert—'Twill be impoſſible to ſleep.

div.stage: Exit Miſs Dorrillon, leading off Lady Priory.

sp.speaker: Lady M.
sp.p: Upon my word, my Lord, your plan of management has made your wife unfit for company.

sp.speaker: Lord Pri.
sp.p: So much more ſit to be a wife.

sp.speaker: Lady M.
sp.p: She is abſolutely fatigued with hard labour—for ſhame!—How does houſehold drudgery become her hand?

sp.speaker: Lord Pri.
sp.p: Much better than cards and dice do yours.

div.stage: Exit Lady Mary followed by Lord Priory—Sir William is left on the ſtage alone.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: She "has a heart large enough to receive her enemy."—And by that enemy ſhe means her father. He ſits down, and ſhews marks of inquietude.

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.p: I beg your pardon Mr. Mandred—I hope I don't interrupt you—I only wiſhed to ſpeak to Miſs Dorrillon.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: She is juſt gone into the next room.

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.p: To the concert?

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: Are not you invited?

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.p: Yes; but before I go in, I wiſh to know who are the company—Can you tell whether—a Mr. Bronzeley is there?

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: I know he is.

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.p: Are you acquainted with him?

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: I have met him here frequently.

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.p: And are you certain he is here at preſent?

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: I have reaſon to be certain.

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.p: Any particular reaſon?

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: Your miſtreſs, when his name was announced, went out to him, exclaiming, "he was the moſt charming and accompliſhed man in the world."

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.p: greatly agitated. She loves him, Sir—I have reaſon to believe—to know ſhe loves him. Thus ſhe gives up my happineſs and her own, to gratify the vanity of a man who has no real regard for her; but whoſe predominant paſſion is to enjoy the villainous name of a general ſeducer.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: riſing. Why do you ſuffer it?

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.p: Huſh! Don't repeat what I have ſaid, or I loſe her for ever. I am at preſent under her reſentment; and have juſt ſent into the next room, to aſk, if ſhe were there, to ſpeak with her.

sp.speaker: Miſs Dor.
sp.p: And is it poſſible I was ſent for by you?

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.p: Don't be offended, that I ſhould be uneaſy, and come to atone—

sp.speaker: Miſs Dor.
sp.p: I can't forgive you, Sir; 'tis impoſſible. Going.

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.p: You pardon thoſe, Maria, who offend you more.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: But an ungrateful mind always prefers the unworthy.

sp.speaker: Miſs Dor.
sp.p:
Ah! Mr. Mandred, are you there? playfully And have you undertaken to be ſir George's counſel? If you have I believe he muſt loſe his cauſe. To ſit you for the tender taſk of advocate in love,—have you ever been admitted an honourable member of that court! Have you, with all that ſolemn wiſdom of which you are maſter,
ſtudied Ovid, as our great lawyers ſtudy Blackſtone? If you have—ſhew cauſe—why plaintiff has a right to defendant's heart.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: A man of fortune, of family, and of character, ought at leaſt be treated with reſpect, and with honour.

sp.speaker: Miſs Dor.
sp.p: You mean to ſay, That if A is beloved by B, why ſhould not A be conſtrained to return B's love? Counſellor for defendant—Becauſe, moreover, and beſides B who has a claim on defendant's heart, there are alſo C, D, E, F, and G; all of whom put in their ſeparate claims—and what in this caſe can poor A do? She is willing to part and divide her love, ſhare and ſhare alike; but B will have all or none: ſo poor A muſt remain A by herſelf A.

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.p: Do you think I would accept a ſhare of your heart?

sp.speaker: Miſs Dor.
sp.p: Do you think I could afford to give it you all? "Beſides," ſays defendant's counſellor, I will prove that plaintiff B has no heart to give defendant in return—he has, indeed a pulſation on the left ſide; but as it never beat with any thing but ſuſpicion and jealouſy; in the laws of love, it is not termed, admitted, or conſidered a heart. Going.

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.p: Where are you going?

sp.speaker: Miſs Dor.
sp.p: To the muſic-room, to be ſure: and if you follow me, it ſhall be to ſee me treat every perſon there better than yourſelf—and Mr. Bronzely, whom you hate, to ſee me treat him beſt of all. Exit.

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.p: I muſt follow you though to death. Exit.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: Fool! And yet am I nearly as weak as he is? Elſe why do I linger in this houſe? Why feed my hopes with ſome propitious moment to waken her to repentance? Why ſtill anxiouſly wiſh to ward off ſome dreaded fate?—If we would marry Sir George, now—if ſhe would give me only one proof of diſcretion, I think I would endeavour to take her to my heart.

div.stage: Enter Mr. Bronzely, in great haſte.

sp.speaker: Bron.
sp.p: My dear Sir, will you do me the greateſt favour in the world?—you muſt do it in an inſtant too. Do, my dear Sir, aſk no queſtion; but lend me your coat for a ſingle moment, and take mine—only for a moment—I cannot explain my reaſons, now, my impatience is ſo great;—but, the inſtant you have complied, I will inform you of the whole ſecret; and you will for ever rejoice that you granted my requeſt. Pulling off his coat.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: aſide, with great ſcorn. And this very contemptible fellow is the favoured lover of my daughter!—I'll— after a ſtruggle—yes—I'll make myſelf maſter of his ſecret—it may poſſibly concern her—my child—my child's ſafety may depend upon it.

sp.speaker: Bron.
sp.p: Dear Mr. Mandred, no time is to be loſt!

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: This is rather a ſtrange requeſt, Mr. Bronzely. However, your fervency convinces me you muſt have ſome very forcible reaſon.—There's my coat, Sir, Gives it him.

sp.speaker: Bron.
sp.p: Thank you, dear Sir,—a thouſand times.—This goodneſs I ſhall ever remember—this binds me to you for ever!— putting it on. Thank you, Sir, a thouſand times!Bowing dreſſed and compoſed.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: after putting on the other coat. And now. Sir, explain the cauſe of this metamorphoſis—let me have the ſatisfaction to know what advantage will accrue from it; and in what I have to rejoice.

sp.speaker: Bron.
sp.p: Will you promiſe me not to reveal the ſecret, if I truſt you with it?

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: Would you add conditions after the bargain is made? I muſt know your ſecret inſtantly.

sp.speaker: Bron.
sp.p: Then I will diſcloſe it to you voluntarily; and rely on your honour to keep it.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: attentively. Well, Sir.

sp.speaker: Bron.
sp.p: Hark! I thought I heard ſomebody coming!

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: I inſiſt upon the information. Laying hold of him

sp.speaker: Bron.
sp.p: Well, then Sir—well—you ſhall—you ſhall.—Then, Sir—in the ſmall gallery, which ſeparates the muſic-room from the reſt of theſe apartments—in that little gallery, the lamp is juſt unfortunately, gone out.—I was (as unfortunately) coming along, when the whiſking of a woman's gown made me give a ſudden ſtart!—I found a perſon was in the gallery with me, and in the dark.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: Well, Sir!

sp.speaker: Bron.
sp.p: And ſo, confidently aſſuring myſelf, that it was Miſs Dorrillon's waiting-maid, or Lady Mary's waiting-maid, I moſt unluckily claſped my arms around her, and took one kiſs.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: Only one?

sp.speaker: Bron.
sp.p:
Th • re might be half a dozen! I w • n't 〈◊〉
• end to ſwear 〈…〉 dozen, before I knew who ſhe was. My rapidity would not let her breathe at firſt, and ſhe was fairly ſpeechleſs.—But the moment ſhe recovered her breath, ſhe cry'd, "Villian! whoever you are, you ſhall repent this:"—I found it was the voice of a lady to whom I had juſt been introduced in the concert-room▪ one Lady Priory! It ſeems ſhe 〈…〉 to bed at the tune we unhappily met.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: But what has this to do with your coat?

sp.speaker: Bron.
sp.p:
A great deal, Sir—you will find a great deal.—As I perceived ſhe did not know me, I carefully held my tongue—but ſhe with her prudiſh notions, called "Help, and murder!" On which I flew to the door, to get away before the lights could be brought—ſhe ſlew after me: and, as I went out, exclaimed, Don't hope to conceal yourſelf; I ſhall know you among the whole concert-room; for I carry ſciſſors hanging at my ſide, and I have cut a piece off your coat.
Sir William looks haſtily at his coal—on which Bronzely holds up the part cut. —And, ſure enough, ſo ſhe had!

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: in anger And what, Sir, am I to have the diſgrace——

sp.speaker: Bron.
sp.p: Either you or I muſt.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: And do you dare—

sp.speaker: Bron.
sp.p: Conſider, my dear Sir, how much leſs the fault is, if perpetrated by you, than by me! This is the firſt offence of the kind which, I dare ſay, you have committed this many a year; and it will be overlooked in you. But I have been ſuſpected of two or three things of the ſame ſort within a very ſhort time; and I ſhould never be forgiven.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: Nor ought you to be forgiven—It would be ſcandalous in me to connive—

sp.speaker: Bron.
sp.p: But would it not be more ſcandalous to reveal the ſecret of a perſon who confided in you?—who flew to you in diſtreſs, as his friend, the partner of his cares?

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: Your impertinence to me, but more your offence to a woman of virtue, deſerves puniſhment. Yet I think the puniſhment of death, in the way that a man of my Lord Priory's temper might inflict it, much too honourable for you deſerts; ſo I ſave your life for ſome leſs creditable end. I lend you my coat, to diſgrace you by exiſtence; and will go to my chamber, and put on another myſelf. Paſſes Bronzely, in order to retire to his chamber.

div.stage: Enter Lord Priory, meeting him. Sir William ſtarts.

sp.speaker: Bron.
sp.p: going up to Lord Priory. Ah, my Lord! is the concert over? charming muſic! that ſolo was divine.

div.stage: Sir William ſteals to a chair, and ſits down to hide his coat.

sp.speaker: Lord Priory
sp.p: after looking inquiſitively at Bronzely's dreſs. It is time the concert ſhould be over—it had been better it had never begun; for there have been very improper perſons admitted. In great anger.

sp.speaker: Bron.
sp.p: affecting ſurpriſe. Indeed!

sp.speaker: Lord Pri.
sp.p: trembling with rage. I am at a loſs how to act. Draws a chair with violence, and places himſelf down by Sir William—Sir William appears diſconcerted and uneaſy. But if I could find the man to whom this piece of cloth belongs—

sp.speaker: Bron.
sp.p: What! this ſmall piece of woollen cloth?

sp.speaker: Lord Pri.
sp.p: Yes, then I ſhould know how to act. In the mean time, Mr. Mandred, as I know you are a great admirer of my wife Sir William ſtarts , and a grave prudent man of honour, I come to aſk your advice, how I am the moſt likely to find out the villain who has dared to inſult her; for a groſs inſult ſhe has received from one of Mr. Norberry's viſitor's wearing a coat of which this is a part.

sp.speaker: Bron.
sp.p: The villain, no doubt, ſtole out of the houſe immediately.

sp.speaker: Lord Pri.
sp.p: I ordered the ſtreet door to be guarded that inſtant—and you Mr. Bronzely, are now the laſt man whoſe habit I have examined.

sp.speaker: Bron.
sp.p: And you ſee I am perfectly whole. Turning round.

sp.speaker: Lord Pri.
sp.p: I do ſee—I do ſee. Sir William moves about on his chair, and appears greatly embarraſſed. Lord Priory ſtarts up in a violent paſſion—Sir William ſtarts up with him.

sp.speaker: Lord Pri.
sp.p: I'll find him out if he is on earth—I'll find him out if—My paſſion carries me away—I have not coolneſs to detect him myſelf—I'll employ another—I'll ſend Oliver in ſearch. Oliver! calling Oliver! here Oliver! Why don't you anſwer when you are called, you ſtupid, dull, idle, forgetful, blundering, obſtinate, careleſs, ſelf-ſufficient.— Exit in a fury.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: riſing with great dignity And now, Mr. Bronzely, how do you think you are to repay me, for having felt one tranſitory moment of ſhame? Underſtand, Sir, that ſhame is one of the misfortunes to which I have never—

sp.speaker: Bron.
sp.p: aſide to Sir William. Sit down, ſit down, ſit down—hold your tongue, and ſit down.

div.stage: Sir William reluctantly retires to his chair.

sp.speaker: Lady M.
sp.p:
Well, I do moſt cordially rejoice, when peeviſh, ſuſpicious, and cenſorious people, meet with humiliation! I could die with laughing at the
incident which has put both my Lord and my Lady Priory in the greateſt terror, grief, and rage.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: riſing. I am out of all patience. The malicious depravity of perſons in a certain ſphere of life is not to be borne. With firmneſs and ſolemnity. Lady Mary—Mr. Bronzely—

sp.speaker: Bron.
sp.p: in a half whiſper to him. Go away—don't expoſe yourſelf—ſteal out the room—take my advice, and go to-bed—hide yourſelf. So great is my reſpect for you, I would not have you detected for the world.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: I am going to retire, Sir. I would not throw my friend's houſe into confuſion and broils; therefore I am as well pleaſed not to be detected as you can be. Goes to the door, then turns. But before I quit the room, I am irreſiſtibly impelled to ſay—Mr. Bronzely! Lady Mary! while you continue to ridicule all that is virtuous, eſtimable, dignified, your vices moſt aſſuredly will plunge you into that very diſgrace—

div.stage: Enter Oliver, and places the piece of cloth againſt Sir William's coat.

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.p: 'Tis as exact a match as ever was—it fits to a thread. Ha, ha, ha!—Ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: Raſcal!

sp.speaker: Bron.
sp.p: Did not I entreat you to go to bed?

sp.speaker: Lady M.
sp.p: Oh! this is the higheſt gratification I ever knew. My Lord! my Lord. calling.

sp.speaker: Bron.
sp.p: Huſh, huſh?—hold, for heavens ſake.

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.p: But mercy and goodneſs defend us! who would have thought of this grave gentleman? Ha, ha, ha!—I can tell you what, Sir; my Lord will be in a terrible paſſion with you. This houſe won't hold you both; and I am ſure I hate to make miſchief.—Mum—I'll ſay nothing about it. clapping Sir William on the ſhoulder And ſo make yourſelf eaſy.

sp.speaker: Bron.
sp.p: on the other ſide of Sir William. Yes, make yourſelf eaſy.

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.p:
A good ſervant ſhould ſometimes be a peacemaker—for my part, I have faults of my own,
and ſo, I dare ſay, has that gentlewoman. But of ail the birds in the wood, how came you to make up to my Lady? Ha, ha, ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Bron.
sp.p: No jeſts—no jeſts. Mr. Mandred is my friend—my very good friend—and he is not ſo much to blame as you think, for—Good night, my dear Sir. Heaven bleſs you. I thank you a thouſand times. Good night. Shaking hands with Sir William, and leading him towards the door.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: with ſteady compoſure Good night.—Good night, Lady Mary. Exit.

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.p: Why, he never ſo much as once ſaid he was obliged to me.

sp.speaker: Lady M.
sp.p: I am ſure, if you do not diſcover this to your maſter, I will.

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.p: Oh! as that old gentleman had not manner to ſay "thank you for your kindneſs," I'll go tell my Lord directly. Exit

sp.speaker: Bron.
sp.p: running after him No, no, no—ſtop Oliver. He is gone!

sp.speaker: Lady M.
sp.p: What makes you thus anxious and concerned, Bronzely? Now, I wiſh I may ſuffer death, if, till I came into this room, I did not think you were the offender.

sp.speaker: Bron.
sp.p: I! I indeed!—No, if I could have been tempted to offend any woman in this houſe in a ſimilar manner, it could have been none but you.

sp.speaker: Lady M.
sp.p: No, Bronzely, no; I have been too partial to you, to have any remaining claims.—Hark! don't I hear Lord Priory's voice in a dreadful rage?

sp.speaker: Bron.
sp.p: Then Oliver has accuſed him. What ſhall I do to prevent miſchief? Dear Lady Mary, as it is not proper for me to ſtay here any longer uninvited, do you run and try to pacify my Lord Priory. Tell him Mandred does not ſleep here to-night; and in the morning you are ſure he will make an apology.

sp.speaker: Lady M.
sp.p: I will do as you deſire—but I know Mr. Mandred ſo well, that I am ſure he will not.

sp.speaker: Bron.
sp.p: Then I will for him. Early in the morning, I'll wait on Lady Priory, and beg pardon in his name without his knowing it. Yes, I have got poor Mandred into a difficulty, and it is my duty to get him out of it. And then I ſhall not only ſerve him, but have one interview more with that heavenly woman. Exit.

div.head: SCENE I. An Apartment at Mr. NORBERRY's.
div.stage: Enter Mr. Bronzely followed by a Servant.

sp.speaker: BRONZELY
sp.p: I AM early, I know: but Lady Priory is the only perſon I wiſh to ſee. Is my Lord with her?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: No, Sir, Lord Priory ſat up very late, and is in bed yet.

sp.speaker: Bron.
sp.p: Acquaint Lady Priory, a perſon comes on urgent buſineſs, begs to ſpeak with her. If ſhe aſks my name you know it. Exit Servant. Pray heaven ſhe may bleſs me with her ſight! Never was ſo enchanted by a woman in my life! and never was played ſuch a trick in my life. I am half inflamed by love, and half by ſpite, once more to attempt her.

div.stage: Enter Lady Priory—he bows moſt reſpectfully—ſhe curtſies.

sp.speaker: Bron.
sp.p: Lady Priory, I am come—I am come upon rather an aukward, yet a very ſerious buſineſs; it was my misfortune to be among that company yeſterday evening, where an unworthy member of it had the inſolence to offer an affront to your reſplendent virtue—

sp.speaker: Lady Pri.
sp.p: ——I have ſome houſehold accounts to arrange, and breakfaſt to make for my Lord as ſoon as he leaves his chamber: therefore, if you pleaſe, Sir, proceed to the buſineſs on which you came, without thinking it neceſſary to interrupt it by any compliment to me.

sp.speaker: Bron.
sp.p: I will be conciſe, Madam.—In a word, I wait upon you from Mr. Mandred, with the moſt humble apology for his late conduct, which he acknowledges to have been indecorous and unwarrantable; but he truſts, that in conſequence of the conceſſion which I now make for him, the whole matter will, from this hour, be buried in oblivion.

sp.speaker: Lady Pri.
sp.p: going to the ſide of the ſcene, and ſpeaking. If my Lord is at leiſure, tell him there is a gentleman would be glad to ſpeak with him.— to Bronzely I am ſorry, Sir, you ſhould know ſo little of the rules of our family, as to ſuppoſe that I could give an anſwer upon any ſubject in which my huſband condeſcends to be concerned. Going.

sp.speaker: Bron.
sp.p: Lady Priory, ſtop. You can at leaſt uſe your power to ſoften Lord Priory's reſentment; and unleſs this apology is accepted, a challenge muſt follow, and poſſibly he may fall.

sp.speaker: Lady Pri.
sp.p: Poſſibly. Sighing.

sp.speaker: Bron.
sp.p: You are intereſted for your huſband's life?

sp.speaker: Lady Pri.
sp.p: Certainly. But I ſet equal value on his reputation. Going.

sp.speaker: Bron.
sp.p: Hear me one ſentence more.—I cannot part from her. Aſide. Oh! I have ſomething of ſuch importance to communicate to you—and yet—I know not how!

sp.speaker: Lady Pri.
sp.p: Then tell it to my huſband.

sp.speaker: Bron.
sp.p: Hem, hem. Aſide. Oh! Lady Priory, if the inſult of laſt night has given you offence, ſhould you not wiſh to be informed of a plan laid for yet greater violence?She ſtarts.

sp.speaker: Lady Pri.
sp.p: Good heaven!

sp.speaker: Bron.
sp.p:
This is neither time nor place to diſcloſe what I wiſh to ſay—nor do I know how to find an opportunity to ſpeak with you alone, free from the poſſibility of intruſion; where I could reveal a
ſecret to you, which is connected with your happineſs, with your future peace.

sp.speaker: Lady Pri.
sp.p: You alarm me beyond expreſſion. I am going to my own houſe about twelve o'clock, for a couple of hours—follow me there.

sp.speaker: Bron.
sp.p: And I ſhall be admitted?

sp.speaker: Lady Pri.
sp.p: Certainly—for you have excited my curioſity, and I am all impatience to hear what you have to communicate that ſo much concerns me.

sp.speaker: Bron.
sp.p: Promiſe then, no perſon but yourſelf ſhall ever know of it. She heſitates. Unleſs you promiſe this, I dare not truſt you.

sp.speaker: Lady Pri.
sp.p: after a ſecond heſitation. I do promiſe, I promiſe faithfully.

sp.speaker: Bron.
sp.p: Your word is ſacred, I rely.

sp.speaker: Lady Pri.
sp.p: Moſt ſacred.

sp.speaker: Bron.
sp.p: And you promiſe that no one but yourſelf ſhall know of the appointment we have made now at your houſe, nor of the ſecret which I will then diſcloſe to you.

sp.speaker: Lady Pri.
sp.p: I promiſe faithfully that no one but myſelf ſhall ever know of either.

sp.speaker: Bron.
sp.p: Remember then to be there alone, exactly—

sp.speaker: Lady Pri.
sp.p: At one o'clock.

sp.speaker: Bron.
sp.p: And that your ſervants have orders to ſhew me to you.

sp.speaker: Lady Pri.
sp.p: I am too much intereſted to forget one circumſtance.

sp.speaker: Bron.
sp.p: Go now then to Lord Priory with Mr. Mandred's apology—and urge his acceptance of it, with all that perſuaſion by which you are formed to govern, while you appear to obey.

sp.speaker: Lady Pri.
sp.p: I will preſent the apology as I received it from you; but do not imagine I dare give my opinion upon it, unleſs I am deſired.

sp.speaker: Bron.
sp.p: But if you are deſired, you will then ſay—

sp.speaker: Lady Pri.
sp.p: Exactly what I think. Exit.

sp.speaker: Bron.
sp.p:
I'll do a meritorious act this very day. This poor woman lives in ſlavery with her huſband. I'll give her an opportunity to run away from him. When we meet, I'll have a poſt-chaiſe waiting a few doors from her houſe; boldly tell her that I
love her; and— Enter Miſs Dorrillon.—My dear Miſs Dorrillon, I could not ſleep all night, but am come thus early on purpoſe to complain of your treatment of me during the whole of yeſterday evening. Not one look did you glance towards me—and there I ſat in miſerable ſolitude up in one corner, the whole time of the concert.

sp.speaker: Miſs Dor.
sp.p: I proteſt I did not ſee you!—and, ſtranger ſtill! never thought of you.

sp.speaker: Bron.
sp.p: You then like another better than you do me?

sp.speaker: Miſs Dor.
sp.p: I do.

sp.speaker: Bron.
sp.p: Do you tell him ſo?

sp.speaker: Miſs Dor.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Bron.
sp.p: You tell him you like me the beſt.

sp.speaker: Miſs Dor.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Bron.
sp.p: Then I will believe what you ſay to him, not what you ſay to me—And though you charge me with inconſtancy, yet I ſwear to you, my beloved Maria, taking her hand that no woman, no woman but yourſelf—

div.stage: Enter Sir William, and ſtarts at ſeeing his Daughter in ſuch cloſe converſation with Bronzely.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: aſide. How familiar!—my eyes could not be ſhocked with a ſight half ſo wounding to my heart as this!

sp.speaker: Bron.
sp.p: apart to Miſs Dorrillon. Huſh! you have heard the ſtory; but don't laugh at him now. He is in a deviliſh ill humour, and it will all fall on me. Go away.—It's a very good ſtory, but laugh at him another time.

sp.speaker: Miſs Dor.
sp.p: I don't believe a word of the ſtory; yet, as a received opinion, it is a charming weapon for an enemy, and I long to uſe it.

sp.speaker: Bron.
sp.p:
Not now, not now—becauſe I have ſome buſineſs with him, and 'twill put him out of temper. He hands her to the door.
Exit Miſs Dorrillon.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p:
looking ſtedfaſtly after her. Poor girl! poor girl! I am not yet ſufficiently enraged againſt her, not to compaſſionate her for her choice!—Is
this the man who is to be, for life, her companion, her protector?

sp.speaker: Bron.
sp.p: Well, Mr. Mandred, I believe I have ſettled it.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: Settled what anxiouſly.

sp.speaker: Bron.
sp.p: At leaſt I have done all in my power to ſerve you: perhaps you don't know that Mr. Oliver divulged the whole affair. But I have waited on my Lady Priory, and I do believe I have ſettled it with her, to manage it ſo with my Lord, that every thing ſhall be huſhed up. You may expect a few jeſts among your female acquaintance, and a few epigrams in the news-papers; but I verily believe every thing material is ſafe.—Is there any farther ſatisfaction which you demand from me?

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: Not at preſent—a man is eaſily ſatisfied who poſſeſſes both courage and ſtrength to do himſelf right, whenever he feels his wrongs oppreſſive. I have as yet found but little inconvenience from the liberties you have taken with me; and what, juſt at this time far more engages my attention than revenge, is, an application to you for intelligence. Without farther preface, do you pay your addreſſes to the young lady who lives in this houſe?

sp.speaker: Bron.
sp.p: Yes I do, Sir—I do.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: You know, I ſuppoſe, which of the two ladies I mean?

sp.speaker: Bron.
sp.p: Which ever you mean, Sir, 'tis all the ſame, for I pay my addreſſes to them both.

sp.speaker: Sir W.
sp.p: ſtarting. To them both!

sp.speaker: Bron.
sp.p: I always do.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: And pray, which of them do you love?

sp.speaker: Bron.
sp.p: Both, Sir——upon my word, both—I aſſure you, both.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: But you don't intend to marry both?

sp.speaker: Bron.
sp.p:
I don't intend to marry either: and indeed, the woman whom I love beſt in the world, has a huſband already. Do you ſuppoſe I could confine my affections to Lady Mary or Miſs Dorrillon, after Lady Priory appeared? do you ſuppoſe I did not know who it was I met laſt night in the dark? wherever I viſit, Mr. Mandred, I always make love
to every woman in the houſe: and I aſſure you they all expect it—I aſſure you, Sir, they all expect it.

div.stage: Sir William walks about in anger.

sp.speaker: Bron.
sp.p: Have you any further commands for me?

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: Yes, one word more.—And you really have no regard for this girl who parted from you as I came in?

sp.speaker: Bron.
sp.p: Oh yes, pardon me—I admire, I adore, I love her to diſtraction: and if I had not been ſo long acquainted with my Lady Mary, nor had ſeen my Lady Priory laſt night, I ſhould certainly call Sir George Evelyn to an account for being ſo perpetually with her.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: anxiouſly. Do you think he loves her?

sp.speaker: Bron.
sp.p: Yes, I dare ſay, as well as I do.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: Do you think ſhe likes him?

sp.speaker: Bron.
sp.p: I think ſhe likes me.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: But, with your method of affection, ſhe may like him too.

sp.speaker: Bron.
sp.p: She may, ſhe may.—In ſhort, there is no anſwering for what ſhe likes—all whim and flightineſs—acquainted with every body—coquetting with every body—and in debt with every body. Her mind diſtracted between the claims of lovers, and the claims of creditors,—the anger of Mr. Norberry, and the want of intelligence from he father!

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: She is in a hopeful way.

sp.speaker: Bron.
sp.p: Oh, it would be impoſſible to think of marrying her in her preſent ſtate—for my part, I can't—and I queſtion whether Sir George would.—But if her father comes home, and gives her the fortune that was once expected, why then I may poſſibly marry her myſelf.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: firmly. She will never have any fortune—I come from India lately, you know; and you may take my word her father is not coming over, nor will he ever come.

sp.speaker: Bron.
sp.p: Are you ſure of that?

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: Very ſure.

sp.speaker: Bron.
sp.p:
Then keep it a ſecret—don't tell her ſo
—poor thing! it would break her heart. She is doatingly fond of her father.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: Hah! how!—oh no, ſhe can have no remembrance of him.

sp.speaker: Bron.
sp.p: Not of his perſon, perhaps: but he has conſtantly correſponded with her; ſent her preſents, and affectionate letters—and you know a woman's heart is eaſily impreſſed.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: I never heard her mention her father.

sp.speaker: Bron.
sp.p: Not to you—but to us who are kind to her, ſhe talks of him continually. She cried bitterly the other day when the laſt ſhip came in, and there was no account of him.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: Did ſhe? did ſhe? eagerly. Aye, I ſuppoſe ſhe is alarmed leſt he ſhould be dead, and all his fortune loſt.

sp.speaker: Bron.
sp.p: No, I believe her affection for him is totally unconnected with any intereſted views. I have watched her upon that head, and I believe ſhe loves her father ſincerely.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: wiping a tear from his eye. I believe it does not matter whom ſhe loves!

sp.speaker: Bron.
sp.p: By the bye, ſhe hates you.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: I thought ſo.

sp.speaker: Bron.
sp.p: Yes, you may be ſatisfied of that. Yes, ſhe even quarrelled with me the other day for ſpeaking in your favour: you had put her in a paſſion, and ſhe ſaid no one that loved her, ought to have any reſpect for you.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: I am much obliged to her—very much obliged to her. Did ſhe ſay nothing more?

sp.speaker: Bron.
sp.p: Only that you were ill-natured, dogmatic, cruel and inſolent. Nothing more.—And ſay what ſhe will againſt you, you know you can be even with her.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: Yes, I can be even with her, and I will be even with her.

div.stage: Enter Lord Priory, and takes Bronzely on one ſide

sp.speaker: Lord Pri.
sp.p:
I have accepted this man's apology:—I will not call him to a ſerious account; but he ſhall not eſcape every kind of reſentment.—I am reſolved
to laugh at him; to turn the whole affair into mirth and good humour; at the ſame time to gall him to the heart. Good morning, Mr. Mandred?—Let me go, violently to Bronzely I muſt joke with him.

sp.speaker: Bron.
sp.p: But neither your voice nor your looks agree with your words.

sp.speaker: Lord Pri.
sp.p: Mr. Mandred, I did intend to be angry—but it would give too reſpectable an air to a baſe act on—and ſo I am come to laugh at you. Enter Lady Mary. And I am ſure Lady Mary, will join even me, in laughing at this man of gallantry.

sp.speaker: Lady M,
sp.p: Oh! I am abſolutely afraid to come near the Tarquin!

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: You need not, Lady Mary; for there can be no Tarquin without a Lucretia.

sp.speaker: Lord Pri.
sp.p: However, Mr. Mandred, it is proper I ſhould tell you, I accept the apology you have made: but at the ſame time—

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: haſtily What do you mean, my Lord? I have made no apology.

sp.speaker: Bron.
sp.p: Yes, yes, you have—I called and made one for you.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: Made an apology for me! You have juſt gone one ſtep too far then I inſiſt—

sp.speaker: Bron.
sp.p:
Drawing Sir William on one ſide. I will—I will—I will ſet every thing to rights. It would be baſe in me if I did not; and I will. Turns to Lord Priory and Lady Mary. Yes, Mr. Mandred, I will retrieve your character at the expence of my own. I am more able to contend with the frenzy of a jealous huſband than you are.— Enter Miſs Dorrillon and Sir George Evelyn.—I am happy to ſee you—you are juſt come in time to hear me clear the grave, the reſpectable character of my friend Mr. Mandred, and to ſtigmatiſe my own.—My Lord, vent all your anger and your ſatire upon me. It was I (pray believe me, I beg you will; don't doubt my word), it was I who committed the offence of which my friend, the man I
reſpect and reverence, ſtands accuſed—It was I who offended my Lady Priory, and then—

sp.speaker: Lord Pri.
sp.p: It can't be——I won't believe you.

sp.speaker: Lady M.
sp.p: But how generous and noble in him to take it upon himſelf!

sp.speaker: Bron.
sp.p: to Sir William. There! what can I do more? You ſee they won't believe me;—Tell me what I can do more? Can I do any thing more?—My feelings are wounded on your account, more than on my own, and compel me, though reluctantly, to quit the room. Exit.

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.p: I am at a loſs which to admire moſt, the warmth of Mr. Bronzely's friendſhip, or the coldneſs of Mr. Mandred's gratitude!

sp.speaker: Lady M.
sp.p: Oh! if it were not for that happy ſteadineſs of feature, he could not preach rectitude of conduct as he does.

sp.speaker: Lord Pri.
sp.p: going up to Sir William. Eloquent admoniſher of youth!

sp.speaker: Miſs Dor.
sp.p: going to him. Indeed, my rigid monitor, I cannot but expreſs admiration, that, under thoſe auſtere looks, and that ſullen brow, there ſtill ſhould lurk—

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: Have a care—don't proceed—ſtop where you are—dare not you complete a ſentence that is meant to mock me.—I have borne the impertinence of this whole company with patience, with contempt; but dare you to breathe an accent ſuſpicious of my conduct, and I will inſtantly teach you how to reſpect me, and to ſhrink with horror from yourſelf. She ſtands motionleſs in ſurpriſe.

sp.speaker: Lord Pri.
sp.p: What a paſſion he is in! Compoſe yourſelf, Mr. Mandred.

sp.speaker: Miſs Dor.
sp.p: I proteſt, Mr. Mandred—

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: Raiſing his voice. Dare not to addreſs yourſelf to me.

sp.speaker: Lady M.
sp.p: Did you ever hear the like?—And I vow ſhe looks awed by him!

sp.speaker: Lord Pri.
sp.p: How ſtrange, that a man can't command his temper!

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.p:
Mr. Mandred, permit me to ſay, I have ever wiſhed to treat you with reſpect—nor would
I be raſh in laying that wiſh aſide.—Yet, I muſt now take upon me to aſſure you, that if you think to offend every lady in this houſe with impunity, you are miſtaken.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: Sir George, if you mean to frighten me by your threats, I laugh at you—but if your warmth is really kindled, and by an attachment to that unworthy object, pointing to Miſs Dorrillon I only pity you.

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.p: Inſufferable!— going up to him.—Inſtantly make an atonement for what you have ſaid, or expect the conſequence!

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: And pray, Sir George, what atonement does your juſtice demand?

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.p: Retract your words—Acknowledge you were groſsly deceived, when you ſaid Miſs Dorrillon was unworthy.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: Retract my words!

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.p: Were they not unjuſt?—Is it a reproach, that, enveloped in the maze of faſhionable life, ſhe has yet preſerved her virtue unſuſpected? That, encumbered with the expences conſequent to her connections, ſhe has proudly diſdained even from me the honourable offer of pecuniary aid? that her fond hope ſtill fixes on the return of an abſent parent, whoſe bleſſing ſhe impatiently expects? and that I ſhould have watched her whole conduct with an eye of ſcrutinizing jealouſy, and yet have only beheld that which makes me aſpire, as the ſummit of earthly happineſs to become her huſband?

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: Young man, I admire your warmth with great fervour and affection There is much compaſſion, and benevolence, and charity, in ſometimes miſtaking the vicious for the virtuous; and if in the heat of contention I have ſaid a word reflecting on your character, I am ready to avow my error, and before this company to beg your pardon.

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.p: That is not enough, Sir— taking Miſs Dorrillon by the hand and leading her forward —you muſt aſk this lady's pardon.

div.stage: Sir William ſtarts and turns his face away, ſtrongly impreſſed.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: Aſk her pardon! Though I forgive ſome inſults, I will not this.—Aſk her pardon?—

sp.speaker: Miſs Dor.
sp.p: Nay, nay, Sir George, you have no buſineſs with Mr. Mandred's quarrels and mine—Reſerve your heroic courage for ſome nobler purpoſe than a poor woman's reputation.

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.p: Point out a nobler, and I'll give up this.

sp.speaker: Lady M.
sp.p: There is none ſo noble! And I wiſh, Sir George, you would undertake to vindicate mine.

sp.speaker: Lord Pri.
sp.p: Come, Lady Mary, let us retire, and leave theſe two irritable men to themſelves.

sp.speaker: Lady M.
sp.p: Come Maria, let us leave them alone. He'll teach Mr. Mandred to be civil for the future.

sp.speaker: Miſs Dor.
sp.p: in great agitation. Dear madam, I would not leave them alone for the world!

sp.speaker: Lady M.
sp.p: Then, my Lord, you and I will; they have no offenſive weapons; ſo we may venture to leave them.

sp.speaker: Lord Pri.
sp.p: This comes of being too warm in converſation! This comes of being in a paſſion!

div.stage: Exeunt Lord Priory and Lady Mary.

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.p: While there is a female preſent, I have only to ſay—good morning, Mr. Mandred. Going.

sp.speaker: Miſs Dor.
sp.p: catching hold of him. For once I give up my pride to ſoften yours, Come do not look thus determined!—I am ſure Mr. Mandred did not mean to offend me; the words he made uſe of fell from his lips by accident.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: They did not—I meant them—I mean them ſtill—and I repeat them.

sp.speaker: Miſs Dor.
sp.p:
to Sir William. Now, how can you be ſo provoking?—Nay, hold, Sir George, he offers to go you ſhall not go away with that frowning brow. She draws him gently towards Sir William, then takes Sir William's hand. Nor you, with yours.—Come, ſhake hands for my ſake.—Now, as I live Sir George, Mr. Mandred's hand feels warmer and kinder than yours—he tries to draw it back, but he has not the heart. Sir William ſnatches it away as by compulſion. —Thou art a ſtrange perſonage!—thou wilt not ſuffer me either to praiſe or diſpraiſe thee.—Come, Sir George,
make up this difference—for if you were to fight and Mr. Mandred was to fall—

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: What then?

sp.speaker: Miſs Dor.
sp.p: Why, "I could better ſpare a better man."

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: How!

sp.speaker: Miſs Dor.
sp.p: I ſee you are both ſullen, both obſtinate, and I have but one reſource.—Sir George, if you aſpire to my hand, dare not to lift your's againſt Mr. Mandred. He and I profeſs to be enemies; but if I may judge of his feelings by my own, we have but paſſing enmities.—I bear him no malice, nor he me, I dare be ſworn. Therefore, Sir, lift but your arm againſt him, or inſult him with another word, and our intercourſe is for ever at an end.

div.stage: Sir George and Sir William ſtand for ſome time ſilent.

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.p: Why is it in the power of one woman to make two men look ridiculouſly?

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: I am at a loſs to know, Sir, whether you and I part friends or enemies.—However, call on me in the way you beſt like, and you will find me ready to meet you either as an enemy, or as a friend. Exeunt ſeparately.

div.head: SCENE I. A Hall in Lord Priory's.

sp.speaker: Firſt SERVANT.
sp.p: DO you hear, Mr. Porter, you are to admit no perſon but Mr. Bronzely.

sp.speaker: 2d. Ser.
sp.p: Mr. Bronzely—very well— a loud rapping—and there I ſuppoſe he is.

sp.speaker: 1ſt. Ser.
sp.p: looking through the window. Yes; that I believe is his carriage.— To third Ser.—Let my Lady know. Exit third Sir.

sp.speaker: Bron.
sp.p: You are ſure Lady Priory is at home?

sp.speaker: 1ſt. Ser.
sp.p: Yes. Sir, and gave orders to admit nobody but you.

sp.speaker: Bron.
sp.p: Has ſhe been ſome time at home?

sp.speaker: 1ſt. Ser.
sp.p: Yes, Sir; I dare ſay my Lady came from Mr. Norberry's half an hour ago.

sp.speaker: Bron.
sp.p: Waiting for me half an hour— aſide—Shew me to her inſtantly.

div.head: SCENE II. An Apartment at Lord Priory's.
div.stage: Enter Bronzely and Lady Priory on oppoſite ſides.

sp.speaker: Bron.
sp.p: My dear Lady Priory, how kind you are not to have forgotten your promiſe.

sp.speaker: Lady Pri.
sp.p: How was it poſſible I ſhould? I have been ſo anxious for the intelligence you have to communicate, that it was pain to wait till the time arrived.

sp.speaker: Bron.
sp.p: Thus invited, encouraged to ſpeak, I will ſpeak boldly—and I call heaven to witneſs, that what I am going to ſay——

sp.speaker: Lady Pri.
sp.p: No, ſtay a moment longer—don't tell me juſt yet— liſtening towards the ſide of the ſcenes—for I wiſh him to hear the very beginning?

sp.speaker: Bron.
sp.p: Who, hear the very beginning?

sp.speaker: Lord Pri.
sp.p: I have not kept you waiting, I hope. My Lawyer ſtopt me on buſineſs, or I ſhould have been here ſooner.—My dear Mr. Bronzely— going up to him—I thank you a thouſand times for the intereſt you take in my concerns; and I come prepared with proper coolneſs and compoſure to hear the ſecret with which you are going to entruſt us.

sp.speaker: Bron.
sp.p:
The ſecret!—yes, Sir—The ſecret which I was going to diſcloſe to my Lady Priory—
Ha, Ha, ha!—But, my Lord, I am afraid it is of too frivolous a nature for your attention.

sp.speaker: Lord Pri.
sp.p: I account nothing frivolous which concerns my wife.

sp.speaker: Bron.
sp.p: Certainly, my Lord, certainly not.

sp.speaker: Lord Pri.
sp.p: Beſides; ſhe told me it was of the utmoſt importance. Did not you?angrily.

sp.speaker: Lady Pri.
sp.p: He ſaid ſo.

sp.speaker: Bron.
sp.p: And ſo it was—it was of importance then—juſt at the very time I was ſpeaking to Lady Priory on the ſubject.

sp.speaker: Lady Pri.
sp.p: You ſaid ſo but this very moment.

sp.speaker: Lord Pri.
sp.p: Come, come, tell it immediately, whatever it is. Come, let us hear it.— after waiting ſome time Why, Sir, you look as if you were aſhamed of it! What can be the meaning of this?

sp.speaker: Bron.
sp.p: To be plain, my Lord, my ſecret will diſcloſe the folly of a perſon for whom I have a ſincere regard.

sp.speaker: Lord Pri.
sp.p: No matter—let every fool look like a fool, and every villain be known for what he is—Tell your ſtory.

sp.speaker: Lady Pri.
sp.p: How can you deprive me of the pleaſure you promiſed? You ſaid it would prevent every future care.

sp.speaker: Lord Pri.
sp.p: Explain, Sir. I begin to feel myſelf not quite ſo compoſed as I expected. You never, perhaps, ſaw me in a paſſion—ſhe has—and if you were once to ſee me really angry—

sp.speaker: Bron.
sp.p: Then, my Lord, I am apt to be paſſionate too—and I boldly tell you, that what I had to reveal, though perfectly proper, was meant for Lady Priory alone to hear. I entreated your Ladyſhip not to mention to my Lord that I had any thing to communicate, and you gave me a ſolemn promiſe you would not.

sp.speaker: Lady Pri.
sp.p: Upon my honour, during our whole converſation upon that ſubject, you never named my Lord Priory's name.

sp.speaker: Bron.
sp.p: I charged you to keep what I had to tell you a profound ſecret.

sp.speaker: Lady Pri.
sp.p: Yes; but I thought you underſtood could have no ſecrets from my huſband.

sp.speaker: Bron.
sp.p: You promiſed no one ſhould know it but yourſelf.

sp.speaker: Lady Pri.
sp.p: He is myſelf.

sp.speaker: Lord Pri.
sp.p: How, Mr. Bronzely, did you ſuppoſe ſhe and I were two? Perhaps you did, and that we wanted a third. Well, I quite forgive you for your ſilly miſtake, and laugh at you, ha, ha, ha! as I did at Mandred.— ſeriouſly—Did you ſuppoſe, Sir, we lived like perſons of faſhion of the modern time? Did you imagine that a woman of her character could have a wiſh, a deſire, even a thought, a ſecret from her huſband?

sp.speaker: Bron.
sp.p: It is amazing to find ſo much fidelity the reward of tyranny!

sp.speaker: Lady Pri.
sp.p: Sir—I ſpeak with humility—I would not wiſh to give offence— timidly—But to the beſt of my obſervation and underſtanding, your ſex, in reſpect to us, are all tyrants. I was born to be the ſlave of ſome of you—I make the choice to obey my huſband.

sp.speaker: Lord Pri.
sp.p: Yes, Mr. Bronzely; and I believe it is more for her happineſs to be my ſlave, than your friend—to live in fear of me, than in love with you—Lady Priory, leave the room.

sp.speaker: Lord Pri.
sp.p: Do you ſee—Did you obſerve the glow of truth and candour which teſtifies that woman's faith? and do you not bluſh at having attempted it? Call me a tyrant! Where are the ſigns? Oh, if every married man would follow my ſyſtem in the management of his wife, every impertinent lover would look juſt as fooliſh as you!

sp.speaker: Bron.
sp.p: This is all boaſting, my Lord—you live in continual fear—for (without meaning any offence to Lady Priory's honour) you know you dare not truſt her for one hour alone with any man under ſixty.

sp.speaker: Lord Pri.
sp.p: I dare truſt her at any time with a coxcomb

sp.speaker: Bron.
sp.p: That is declaring I am not one—for I am certain you dare not truſt her alone with me.

sp.speaker: Lord Pri.
sp.p: in a paſſion. Yes, with fifty ſuch.

sp.speaker: Bron.
sp.p: But not with one—you are right—it might be dangerous.

sp.speaker: Lord Pri.
sp.p: angrily. No, it would not.

sp.speaker: Bron.
sp.p: ſignificantly. Yes, it would.

sp.speaker: Lord Pri.
sp.p: Have not you had a trial?

sp.speaker: Bron.
sp.p: But you were preſent. You conſtantly follow all her ſteps, watch all ſhe ſays and does. But I believe you are right—wives are not to be truſted.

sp.speaker: Lord Pri.
sp.p: Mine is.

sp.speaker: Bron.
sp.p: No, my dear Lord Priory, you muſt firſt become gentle, before you can poſitively confide in her affection—before you can truſt her in a houſe, or in any place, alone.

sp.speaker: Lord Pri.
sp.p: haſtily. To prove you are miſtaken, I'll inſtantly go back to my friend Norberry's, and leave you here to tell her the ſecret you boaſted. Pay your addreſſes to her, if that is the ſecret—You have my free conſent.

sp.speaker: Bron.
sp.p: My dear friend, I'll accept it.

sp.speaker: Lord Pri.
sp.p: Ay, I ſee you have hopes of ſupplanting me, by calling me your friend.—But can you conceive now that ſhe'll Men to you?

sp.speaker: Bron.
sp.p: You have given me leave to try, and can't recall it.

sp.speaker: Lord Pri.
sp.p: But depend upon it, you will meet with ſome terrible humiliation.

sp.speaker: Bron.
sp.p: Either you or I ſhall.

sp.speaker: Lord Pri.
sp.p: I ſhall laugh to hear you tumbled down ſtairs.

sp.speaker: Bron.
sp.p: You are not to remain on the watch here; you are to return to Mr. Norberry's.

sp.speaker: Lord Pri.
sp.p: Was that the bargain?

sp.speaker: Bron.
sp.p: Don't you remember? you ſaid ſo.

sp.speaker: Lord Pri.
sp.p: Well, if that will give you any ſatisfaction—

sp.speaker: Bron.
sp.p: —It will give me great ſatisfaction.

sp.speaker: Lord Pri.
sp.p: Heaven forgive me, but your confidence makes me laugh. Ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Bron.
sp.p: And yours makes me laugh. Ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Lord Pri.
sp.p: Hah! What brings you here, Oliver? Lady Priory and I are only come home for a few hours.

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.p: I know it, my Lord. I thought nevertheleſs I might be wanted.

sp.speaker: Bron.
sp.p: And ſo you are, good Mr. Oliver. Your Lord deſires you to conduct me to your Lady in the next room, and acquaint her it is with his permiſſion I am come to conclude the converſation which was juſt now interrupted.—Is not that right, my Lord? Are not thoſe words exactly correſponding with your kind promiſe?

sp.speaker: Lord Pri.
sp.p: I believe they are.

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.p: I am "to take Mr. Bronzely to my lady, and tell her you ſent him." Exit Oliver.

sp.speaker: Bron.
sp.p: Now this is a perfect faſhion: and while I ſtep to Lady Priory, do you go and comfort my intended wife, Lady Mary.

sp.speaker: Lord Pri.
sp.p: I hate the faſhion—and were I not ſure you would now be received in a very unfaſhionable manner—

sp.speaker: Bron.
sp.p: No rough dealings, I hope?

sp.speaker: Lord Pri.
sp.p: Oh, you begin to be afraid do you?

sp.speaker: Bron.
sp.p: No——but I have met with an accident or two lately—and I am not ſo well acquainted with ancient uſages as to know in what manner a man of my purſuits would have been treated in former times.

sp.speaker: Lord Pri.
